titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Rained hard the whole day, but cleared up in the evening— I deposited my brother’s remittance at the Branch-Bank— J. Gardner, called at my Office this afternoon— The club was at my house this Evening. All present but judge Dawes, Dr: Elliot and Dr: Spooner.

2. Spent the morning in writing for the meeting of the Society on Friday Evening, and the day, at my Office, upon the discourse for the 22d: instt:— My Mother came to town; dined at Mr: Smith’s, and went in the afternoon to Cambridge— Went to the Ball, which was very full— Danc’d, part of the Evening— Play’d whist with Mr: Buzzey, Coll: Scollay and Mr: Cobb— We came away about Midnight.

3. Doctor Tufts was at my Office this forenoon;—dined with us— As did my mother, and Mrs: Cranch; who return’d from Cambridge; and in the afternoon to Quincy.— Wrote great part of the day— In the evening, our Society met at Mr Emerson’s as we had before agreed upon.— We elected our Officers, conformably to the Constitution. Judge Davis, President; Mr: Emerson, Secretary; Dr Jackson Treasurer— We agreed to increase our funds, to purchase a large chemical apparatus.— I subscribed five additional shares— Mr: Lowell, attended the meeting— As did all the remaining members— I read the synopsis of the first chapter of Lavoisier’s Elements of Chemistry.

4. Both the girls left us, at two hours warning— Pass’d the forenoon at my Office— In the afternoon, I walk’d out as far as Roxbury Street and there met the Chaise— Went in it to Quincy— Found Mr: S. Spear at my father’s.

5. Heard Mr: Porter of Roxbury— He dined with us— Captain Beale here in the Evening— Spent the rest of the day at the Office— Read little however, and wrote proportionally less— Betsey Newcomb returns with me to-morrow.

6. Louisa Smith came to Boston with us to see her sister— Spent the day at my Office, and the evening at home, reading the remainder of Burke’s Speech upon the India-bill, and part of that upon the Nabob of Arcot’s debts.— Letter from Messrs: W. & J. Willing.

7. Meeting of the Directors of Neponset Bridge.— Several reports of Committees were made— Came to no final determination, but voted to meet again the first Tuesday in January— Before the meeting of the General Court— Finished my discourse for the 22d:. Evening at home— Continued to read Burke, on the Nabob of Arcot’s debts.

8. At my Office, untill 3. in the afternoon— Mr: Tudor called on me.— Dined at Mr: Gardner Greene’s, with a company of Gentlemen and Ladies— Played cards there part of the Evening— Remainder of it, with the club at Mr R. Amory’s— Mrs: Adams and Caroline spent the evening at Mrs. Quincy’s.

9. Winter setting in, and we had this day the first know— Part of the day employed in chemical studies. Mr: S. Spear, in the forenoon— Evening at home— Finished Burke’s speech on the Nabob of Arcot’s debts, and read his motion for an Address to the throne in June 1784.

10. Day at my Office, principally employed upon Lavoisier’s Chemistry— Evening at the Society, where I read a synopsis of his work from the second to the fifth chapter inclusive— The chemical apparatus for experiments was produced— We broke up earlier than usual, from an alarm of fire, which proved however to be nothing.

11. The weather being bad, prevented me from going out to Quincy— Forenoon not very busily spent— Dined at Concert-Hall, with the Assistant fire-club— Thirty-five members present— Chose Officers— Daniel Sargent junr. President, and Coll: Jos: May, who offered his Services as Secretary— Spent the Evening at home— Read the first of Young’s Night-thoughts; and some other small poems.

12. Heard Mr S. Willard, the librarian of Harvard College in the forenoon, at Mr: Emerson’s, and Mr: Emerson himself in the afternoon— Read a Sermon of Tillotson, and wrote a letter to my brother— Caroline pass’d the Evening at Mrs: Welsh’s— I call’d for her there at about 9— Mr: Shaw dined at Mr: Codman’s.

13. Spent the day at my Office, but did little business of any kind, from interruption— Evening at home— Read part of Dr: Johnson’s preface to Shakespear— We were invited to Mr: M’Lean’s this evening; but Mrs: Adams being not entirely well sent an apology.

14. A little more industrious this day; though upon subjects different from those which ought to occupy my time. Lavoisier, and the Plymouth settlement— Evening at home— Finished Johnson’s preface to Shakespear, and read one Act of the Tempest.— Mrs: Adams was taken suddenly very ill about an hour after we went to bed. Roused the family, and sent for Dr: Welsh— Who came and gave her Laudanum.

15. Mrs: Adams continued ill, the whole night; but this morning, was somewhat better, and continued so, through the day— Received my tax-bill this morning and paid it— Met with some gentlemen, at 1. o’clock, who have a project for building an house for public-rooms.— Dined at Dr: Danforth’s, with Caroline— Mrs: Adams was not well enough to go out— Mr: and Mrs: Hichborn, Mr: & Mrs. Blake, Mr and Mrs: Howard &c. were there. We came away early— I attended the club at Judge Davis’s.— Dr: Prince, and Captn: James Seaver were there. Home at 9.

16. The weather sets in excessively cold— A Northwest wind blowing with great severity— The ladies intended going to the ball this Evening, but were deterred by the severity of the weather, and by indisposition— Spent the day, and great part of the Evening at my Office. But continually interrupted so that I could do nothing all day— Last of the Evening at home.

17. Fahrenheit’s thermometer was this morning at 2 degrees below 0.— Reaumur’s at 15. The weather continued extremely cold the whole day— We were invited to a ball this Evening, at Mr: Babcock’s; but the extreme cold, with Caroline’s illness induced the ladies to send an excuse— Pass’d the day at my Office, and the Evening, with the Society— Dr: Prince pass’d it with us.

18. The weather began this morning to moderate, and continued to grow milder the whole day; in the afternoon, there fell a little snow. The carriage was sent in for us; but the weather and Caroline’s indisposition prevented the ladies from going out, and I went alone— I was employed all the morning, at my house, and in preparing for my tour to Plymouth.

19. Weather grown so mild as to thaw considerably— Heard Mr: Whitney— Spent all the remainder of the day very busily employed upon a work, which has been too much delayed— Whole evening very assiduous at the office.

20. Walk’d with my father down to the spot where he purposes building a house— We return’d to dinner somewhat late— The remainder of the day and the evening, I was very busily engaged, in the same manner as yesterday— Read my performance to my father, who appeared better satisfied with it than I am.

21. At about 9 this morning, the stage from Boston to Plymouth called for me— The Company were Judge Davis and his lady, Mr: and Mrs: Goodwin, Miss Penelope Russell, Mr: Emerson, and Mr: W. Stevenson. Judge Davis only stop’d to Breakfast, after which we went and join’d the Stage at Newcomb’s tavern where they breakfasted— We then proceeded as far as Duxbury to dinner— But the roads were bad, and it rain’d the greatest part of the day— We had thirteen miles to go after dinner, but by the time we had reach’d Kingstown, it became so dark, and our horses were so tir’d out, that after once being in great danger of oversetting, we concluded to stop for the night at Russell’s tavern in Kingstown— Our accommodations were indifferent.

22. This morning at break of day, we left Kingstown, and about 9 o’clock arrived at Plymouth— Mr: Emerson, Mr: Stevenson and myself stop’d at Judge Thomas’s, by his invitation— After breakfasting and dressing, we visited the rock of the first landing, and walk’d round the town— Then called at Mr: William Davis’s, and afterwards at Mr: Kendall’s the Minister of the parish. From his house we went in procession to the meeting-house; where he made a good prayer—and I delivered the anniversary Oration, commemorating, the first landing of the original settlers at Plymouth— I was an hour and ten minutes, speaking— We then return’d to Mr: William Davis’s, and at two o’clock went to the town-hall to dinner. There was a company of about seventy persons— After dinner I called at General Warren’s, and at his son Henry’s— The old General and his Lady, appear to be broken down with years and infirmities, altogether— Thence I return’d to Mr: Kendall’s to tea— Afterwards to Judge Thomas’s again— Spent part of the Evening at a Ball, where there were assembled about sixty ladies and as many gentlemen— We return’d to supper at Judge Thomas’s with a small company, and about midnight rose from table

23. At six this morning, Mr: Emerson, Mr: Stevenson and myself, after breakfasting, left Plymouth in the stage; We breakfasted again at Duxbury: And reached Newcomb’s tavern at Quincy, about half past 2 o’clock. There we found a carriage waiting for us, and went to my father’s to dinner— Mr: Whitney and Mr: Barrett were there— The stage called for us and hurried us away— We arrived in Boston at about 1/2 past five o’clock, just as the night had set in— The weather was rainy great part of the day; and the roads very bad— I return’d home with a severe cold.

24. My cold extremely troublesome— Pass’d the day chiefly at my Office— In the afternoon I met with some Gentlemen who have subscribed for building a place for public Assemblies— Little was done. Evening at the Society— Read a Synopsis from Lavoisier— Dr: Jackson read also a paper. Weather grows cold again.

25. Christmas day— We had invited some company to dine with us, but they were engaged— Mr: Shaw likewise dined abroad— Mrs: Adams had been very unwell in the Night and was again ill, this afternoon— My cold prevented me wholly from reading or writing— Walk’d in the Mall this afternoon— Evening at home.

26. Went out to Quincy this morning in a chaise with Whitcomb. Dined at my father’s— Heard Mr: Bates in the afternoon— Return’d afterwards to Boston— Reached home at about 7 o’clock.— Evening at home my cold still very troublesome— My Uncle Adams dined with us at my fathers.

27. Forenoon at my Office— Mr: Boylston, Mr: Townsend and Mr: Gardner called there— Between 12 and 1. o’clock— Saw the masonic procession, and heard Mr: Gurley deliver an Oration at the stone chapel— It is the celebration of the festival of St: John the evangelist— Mr: Shaw dined out— I receiv’d and answer’d this Evening a letter from my brother.

28. Pass’d the day at my Office; but with so many visitors that I could do but little— This indeed is so common a case, that I spend less time there than perhaps I should— That is, I go late in the morning and return home early in the afternoon.— Bond for Mr: Boylston— Spent the Evening with the Ladies at Miss Gray’s— There was a numerous company of ladies and gentlemen—mostly young.

29. Mr: Boylston called again at my Office this forenoon— Writing, the principal part of the day— Attended the club this Evening at Dr Dexter’s— I went first to Dr: Elliot’s, supposing by mistake it was there— Compared Sotheby’s and Warton’s versions of the Georgics.—

30. Day again past at the Office much as yesterday— In the Evening I went with the ladies, and with Miss Dexter to the Ball— Danced, part of the Evening, and play’d cards the remainder— We came home about midnight— Miss Dexter came and pass’d the night with Caroline.

31. Writing for my brother, the greater part of the day— Evening with the Society— I was not prepared for reading. Doctor Jackson gave us a lecture which occupied all our time, untill 10. There was a funeral-sermon and procession this afternoon, for Dr: Thacher who died at Savannah the 16th: of this month.

Day. I rise, not very regularly, but between 6 and 8 o’clock— Write or read at home untill 10. Breakfast— Attend the Market, and get to my Office generally at about 11. Spend the forenoon there, reading, writing, in business, or conversing with my friends who occasionally call there— At 2— Come home to dinner— Between 3 and 4. return to my Office, and read or write untill 7. Pass the remainder of the Evening at home reading to the ladies, or at the club, Society, Ball, Assembly, or in Company abroad— Saturday and Sunday commonly at Quincy.

Here I bring one year more to a close, during which I have enjoyed a greater portion of health, than I had for many years before— My wife also has on the whole been more favoured in this respect than at any period since our marriage, and my Child has been well without interruption, excepting the meazles, and on cutting teeth. The loss of my wife’s father is the only heavy affliction that has befallen us in the course of the year— My affairs have prospered less than my wishes, but more than I could reasonably hope— My property has not diminish’d; but its increase has been very small, and my expences have absorb’d almost the whole of my income, in addition to my acquisitions in the course of the year— I have been enabled however to preserve my health, my principles and my Independence, and seldom at the close of the year has it been in my power to look back with less of self-reproach— The only cause of regret which still hangs on me is that Indolence which creeps so insensibly upon my strongest resolutions, and which I have never subdued— The last sentiment with which I would terminate the record of this year, is that of the warmest Gratitude to that kind Providence, which has heaped on me so many favours beyond all I could deserve.
